author: gcolvin
content:
I'm sorry I had to miss the call.  Doctors...

 I think the EIP template has become too rigid over time, drifting too far from IETF approach that <@191378736254287874>, <@492808720615604251> and I partly took as a model, and as I recall we intended our stricter BIP-style template to be subject to some editorial discretion and deference to the author.  And I don't recall links being forbidden, and certainly included too many of them in my proposals. What we do need is EIP-1 guidance on the sparing use of the highest-quality available links, with proper citations to the published literature where available.  Without them Motivation and Rationale sections can be littered with bald assertions.

author: gcolvin
content: So I think there is room to bend the EIP style guide to suit our growing needs.  Unlike <@301186049323958275>, I have no problems with Meta and Informational EIPS.  I'd suggest they could be used judiciously along with high-quality references to pull together a reasonably complete set of design documents.

author: gcolvin
content: But (I repeat myself) I can't think of the reference implementation as a design document.  It's a client, and it will need its own repo and a dedicated team, just like any other client.  I take it that when clients go Final they tag the code that goes on the mainnet, and at that time the relevant EIPs can be updated to reference it.  From there the EIP remains subject to errata if it does not describe the behavior of the mainnet.

author: gcolvin
content: And I'd suggest that we could keep the reference implementation in sync with the EIPs by linking the client team's PRs back to the relevant EIPs.  If we want to close the loop the EIPs can then be updated to refer back to the client teams's PRs.  But not until the EIP goes Final.  And again, the client team needs to take the lead on this.

content: It would be nice if there was a set eip template so if you want to submit one you click a button fill in the form and automatically get assigned an eip number. It then gets posted once it passes initial review. I remember the last eip I submitted I just choose the next sequential number  and that was wrong.

author: sky.cactus
content: The design document that Tim is referring to would be something new.  A place to describe the architecture of large changes, like proof of stake, stake withdraws, or "sharding" (which isn't really sharding anymore).

author: sky.cactus
content: These documents would be quite unconstrained, IIUC I think Tim's main desire is to have a single place to host/store/render theme and a mechanism for giving them unique identifiers (e.g., numbers).

author: sky.cactus
content: Presumably they would be littered with mutable links, references, images, flow charts, sequence diagrams, etc.  We may want to enforce some standardized header for indexing and table presentation reasons but generally they would be "anything goes".

author: sky.cactus
content: For large projects, the design document would likely come first, and then individual specifications would come later in the process (EIPs).

author: sky.cactus
content: For something that crosses many pieces of Ethereum (e.g., touches JSON-RPC + Execution + EVM + Wallet + Consensus), you would draft a separate specification for each isolated piece (right now that is EL + CL + Wallet, but in the future we may break things apart more) and the design document would be the thing that binds them all together in a cohesive way.

author: sky.cactus
content: Someone who is just building an execution client though and doesn't care much about the overall architecture would be able to just focus on the highly technical and very constrained specification document (e.g., EIP), while someone wanting to understand the system as a whole would use the design document.

author: sky.cactus
content: Something that only touches EL (for example) could also have a design document, but I would like to think it wouldn't be a requirement if the author didn't want it.  For example, I don't feel a design document is necessary to push back the difficulty bomb.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think for the work you are doing on the EVM <@683653554631868440>, a design document would be valuable and possible right in line with what you are looking for.  It would be a place where you can rapidly iterate pretty much unconstrained and draft a very clear document.  Then later in the process when things are further along a formal specification would need to be created (EIP or execution spec, depending on which route we end up taking on that front), but that wouldn't be the *starting* place for a large change.

author: sky.cactus
content: This would also let you have one monolithic document that describes the overarching set of changes you are proposing long term, even if they get spread out across multiple hard forks (with each hard fork getting one or more specification changes along the way).

author: sky.cactus
content: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ethereum/EIPs/master/eip-template.md  While it isn't a GUI wizard, you basically just create a pull request with this copied and filled in.

author: gcolvin
content:
Currently we have various approaches to subroutines and procedures from myself and the Ipsilon team. Those are currently specified in 4 or 5 EIPs and a couple of PRs on those.  Not ideal.  A Magicians thread might be the  best place for discussing them, and we might have the EVM Summit coming up.  An Informational EIP might be best for laying out the resulting consensus  at a conceptual level.  This might amount to the design document you have in mind.  A Meta EIP might be appropriate for specifying the mutual dependencies among the agreed on set of EIPs that specify the new opcodes and associated validation rules.  Taken together we would have a complete set of specifications.

Going forward I think that kind of structure might serve your requirements.  If we don't want to use the Informational EIP for the high-level design then we need a new category of document. 
Am I at least in the ballpark?  <@301186049323958275>, <@552133098075193354>

author: gcolvin
content: PS.  My current work has spanned too many changes of the rules to be following the current ones, so I'll just keep on iterating work on the Drafts.  But in general I don't have problems with Drafts changing a lot as they get reviewed and implemented.  And I don't have a problem with work evolving from smaller EIPs towards an overarching design, or the reverse, or some mixture.  You can't herd cats.
